Reviewing the Data

paragraphs.title: 1 - Ensure the environment is prepared for this exercise
paragraphs.text:
%md
If you completed the `Bonus Exercise 1: Clean Device Status Data` in exercise `08 - Transforming Data Using RDDs`, you used Spark to extract the date, maker, device ID, latitude and longitude from the devicestatus.txt data file, and store the results in the HDFS directory `/user/zeppelin/devicestatus_etl`.

*If you did not complete that bonus exercise, use the commands below to check if the `devicestatus_etl` directory has data in it and upload the files to HDFS if needed.

paragraphs.title: 2 - Examine the data
paragraphs.text:
%md
Examine the data in the dataset. Note that the latitude and longitude are the 4th and 5th fields, respectively, as shown in the sample data below:

```
2014-03-15:10:10:20,Sorrento,8cc3b47e-bd01-4482-b500-28f2342679af,
33.6894754264,-117.543308253
    
2014-03-15:10:10:20,MeeToo,ef8c7564-0a1a-4650-a655-c8bbd5f8f943,
37.4321088904,-121.485029632
```

msg.data: Calculating k-means for Device Location

paragraphs.title: 3 - Review the k-means code
paragraphs.text:
%md
The starter code defines convenience functions used in calculating k-means:

- closestPoint: given a (latitude/longitude) point and an array of current center points, returns the index in the array of the center closest to the given point
- addPoints: given two points, return a point which is the sum of the two points -- that is, (x1+x2, y1+y2)
- distanceSquared: given two points, returns the squared distance of the two -- this is a common calculation required in graph analysis

Note that the stub code sets the variable K equal to 5 -- this is the number of means to calculate.

msg.data:
• closestPoint: given a (latitude/longitude) point and an array of current
    center points, returns the index in the array of the center closest to the given
    point
  • addPoints: given two points, return a point which is the sum of the two points –
    that is, (x1+x2, y1+y2)
  • distanceSquared: given two points, returns the squared distance of the two –
    this is a common calculation required in graph analysis

Note that the stub code sets the variable K equal to 5this is the number of
means to calculate.

paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
#  Find K Means of Loudacre device status locations
# 
# Input data: file(s) with device status data (delimited by ',')
# including latitude (4th field) and longitude (5th field) of device locations 
# (lat,lon of 0,0 indicates unknown location)

# NOTE: Use the %paste command to paste this code into iPython!
# Do NOT try to paste using the terminal paste menu.

# for a point p and an array of points, return the index in the array of the point closest to p
def closestPoint(p, points):
    bestIndex = 0
    closest = float("+inf")
    # for each point in the array, calculate the distance to the test point, then return
    # the index of the array point with the smallest distance
    for i in range(len(points)):
        dist = distanceSquared(p,points[i])
        if dist < closest:
            closest = dist
            bestIndex = i
    return bestIndex
    
# The squared distances between two points
def distanceSquared(p1,p2):  
    return (p1[0] - p2[0]) ** 2 + (p1[1] - p2[1]) ** 2

# The sum of two points
def addPoints(p1,p2):
    return [p1[0] + p2[0], p1[1] + p2[1]]

sc.setLogLevel("WARN")

# The device status dataset
filename = "/devsh_loudacre/devicestatus_etl"
    
# K is the number of means (center points of clusters) to find
K = 5

paragraphs.title: 4 - Familiarize yourself with the algorithm
paragraphs.text:
%md
The stub code also sets the variable `convergeDist`. This will be used to decide when the k-means calculation is done -- when the amount the locations of the means changes between iterations is less than `convergeDist`. A "perfect" solution would be 0; this number represents a "good enough" solution. For this exercise, use a value of 0.01.

msg.data: The stub code also sets the variable convergeDist. This will be used to decide when the k-means calculation is done – when the amount the locations of the means changes between iterations is less than convergeDist. A “perfect” solution would be 0; this number represents a “good enough” solution. For this exercise, use a value of 0.01.

paragraphs.title: 5 - Parse the input file
paragraphs.text:
%md
Parse the input file -- which is delimited by commas -- into `(latitude,longitude)` pairs (the 4th and 5th fields in each line). Only include known locations -- that is, filter out `(0,0)` locations. Be sure to persist the resulting RDD because you will access it each time through the iteration.

msg.data: Parse the input file – which is delimited by commas – into (latitude,longitude) pairs (the 4th and 5th fields in each line). Only include known locations – that is, filter out (0,0) locations. Be sure to persist the resulting RDD because you will access it each time through the iteration.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Start the algorithm by sampling the data
paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a K-length array called `kPoints` by taking a random sample of K location points from the RDD as starting means (center points).

For example:
```    
    kPoints = points.takeSample(False, K, 42)
```

msg.data:
Create a K-length array called kPoints by taking a random sample of K location points from the RDD as starting means (center points).

For example, in Python:

kPoints = points.takeSample(False, K, 42)

Or in Scala:

val kPoints = points.takeSample(false, K, 42)

paragraphs.title: 7 - Prepare the algorithm by initializing variables
paragraphs.text:
%md
Initialize a variable called `tempDist` to positive infinity. The variable with be used to determine when to complete the conditional loop in the next step.

paragraphs.title: 8 - Implement the k-means algorithm
paragraphs.text:
%md
Iteratively calculate a new set of K means until the total distance (stored as `tempDist`) between the means calculated for this iteration and the last one is smaller than `convergeDist`. For each iteration:

### ??? Place each subpart in its own notebook paragraph ???
**a.** For each coordinate point, use the provided closestPoint function to map that point to the index in the kPoints array of the location closest to that point. The resulting RDD should be keyed by the index, and the value should be the pair: (point, 1). (The value 1 will later be used to count the number of points closest to a given mean.) For example:

```
    (1, ((37.43210, -121.48502), 1))
    (4, ((33.11310, -111.33201), 1))
    (0, ((39.36351, -119.40003), 1))
    (1, ((40.00019, -116.44829), 1))
    ...
```

**b.** Reduce the result: for each center in the kPoints array, sum the latitudes and longitudes, respectively, of all the points closest to that center, and also find the number of closest points. For example:

```
    (0, ((2638919.87653,-8895032.182481), 74693)))
    (1, ((3654635.24961,-12197518.55688), 101268)))
    (2, ((1863384.99784,-5839621.052003), 48620)))
    (3, ((4887181.82600,-14674125.94873), 126114)))
    (4, ((2866039.85637,-9608816.13682), 81162)))
```

**c.** The reduced RDD should have (at most) K members. Map each to a new center point by calculating the average latitude and longitude for each set of closest points: that is, map (index,(totalX,totalY),n) to (index,(totalX/n, totalY/n)).

**d.** Collect these new points into a local map or array keyed by index.

**e.** Use the provided distanceSquared method to calculate how much the centers "moved" between the current iteration and the last. That is, for each center in kPoints, calculate the distance between that point and the corresponding new point, and sum those distances. That sum is the delta between iterations; when the delta is less than convergeDist, stop iterating.

**f.** Copy the new center points to the kPoints array in preparation for the next iteration.

the pair: (point, 1). (The value 1 will later be used to count the number of

number of closest points. For example:

(0, ((2638919.87653,-8895032.182481), 74693)))
(1, ((3654635.24961,-12197518.55688), 101268)))
(2, ((1863384.99784,-5839621.052003), 48620)))
(3, ((4887181.82600,-14674125.94873), 126114)))

points: that is, map (index,(totalX,totalY),n) to (index,(totalX/
n, totalY/n)).

centers “moved” between the current iteration and the last. That is, for

between iterations; when the delta is less than convergeDist, stop iterating.

f. Copy the new center points to the kPoints array in preparation for the next
iteration.

paragraphs.title: 3 - Review the k-means code
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
#  Find K Means of Loudacre device status locations
# 
# Input data: file(s) with device status data (delimited by ',')
# including latitude (4th field) and longitude (5th field) of device locations 
# (lat,lon of 0,0 indicates unknown location)

# NOTE: Use the %paste command to paste this code into iPython!
# Do NOT try to paste using the terminal paste menu.

# for a point p and an array of points, return the index in the array of the point closest to p
def closestPoint(p, points):
    bestIndex = 0
    closest = float("+inf")
    # for each point in the array, calculate the distance to the test point, then return
    # the index of the array point with the smallest distance
    for i in range(len(points)):
        dist = distanceSquared(p,points[i])
        if dist < closest:
            closest = dist
            bestIndex = i
    return bestIndex
    
# The squared distances between two points
def distanceSquared(p1,p2):  
    return (p1[0] - p2[0]) ** 2 + (p1[1] - p2[1]) ** 2

# The sum of two points
def addPoints(p1,p2):
    return [p1[0] + p2[0], p1[1] + p2[1]]

sc.setLogLevel("WARN")

# The device status dataset
filename = "/user/zeppelin/devicestatus_etl"
    
# K is the number of means (center points of clusters) to find
K = 5

paragraphs.title: 4 - Familiarize yourself with the algorithm
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# ConvergeDist -- the threshold "distance" between iterations at which we decide we are done
convergeDist = .01

paragraphs.title: 5 - Parse the input file
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Split by delimiter, parse  latitude and longitude (4th and 5th fields) into two-element arrays
# Filter out records where lat/long is unavailable -- ie: 0/0 points
points = sc.textFile(filename)\
     .map(lambda line: line.split(","))\
     .map(lambda fields: [float(fields[3]),float(fields[4])])\
     .filter(lambda point: (point[0] != 0) | (point[1] != 0))\
     .persist()

paragraphs.title: 6 - Start the algorithm by sampling the data
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# start with K randomly selected points from the dataset
kPoints = points.takeSample(False, K, 42)
print("Starting K points")
for point in kPoints: print(point)

paragraphs.title: 7 - Prepare the algorithm by initializing variables
8 - Implement the k-means algorithm
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# loop until the total distance between one iteration's points and the next is less than the convergence distance specified
while tempDist > convergeDist:
    # for each point, find the index of the closest kpoint.  map to (index, (point,1))
    closest = points.map(lambda p : (closestPoint(p, kPoints), (p, 1)))
    # For each key (k-point index), reduce by adding the coordinates and number of points
    pointStats = closest.reduceByKey(lambda point_n_pair1,point_n_pair2: (addPoints(point_n_pair1[0],point_n_pair2[0]),point_n_pair1[1]+point_n_pair2[1]))
    # For each key (k-point index), find a new point by calculating the average of each closest point
    newPoints = pointStats.map(lambda index_point_n_pairs: (index_point_n_pairs[0],[index_point_n_pairs[1][0][0]/index_point_n_pairs[1][1],index_point_n_pairs[1][0][1]/index_point_n_pairs[1][1]])).collect()
    # calculate the total of the distance between the current points and new points
    tempDist=0
    for  (i,point) in newPoints: tempDist += distanceSquared(kPoints[i],point)
    print("Distance between iterations:",tempDist)
    # Copy the new points to the kPoints array for the next iteration
    for (i, point) in newPoints: kPoints[i] = point

paragraphs.title: 9 - when all iterations are complete, display the final center points
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark
# Display the final points
print("Final K points")
for point in kPoints: print(point)
